item.title: A Pop-Culture Glossary for ‘Once Upon a Time … in Hollywood’
item.description: Quentin Tarantino’s film is filled with references to TV shows, movies and other totems of midcentury Los Angeles. We explain who’s who and what’s what.
item.dc:creator: Bruce Fretts
item.category: Once Upon a Time in Hollywood (Movie)
item.media:description: From left, Brad Pitt, Leonardo DiCaprio and Al Pacino meet at Musso & Frank Grill in the movie.

item.title: ‘The Blair Witch Project’ at 20: Why It Can’t Be Replicated
item.description: When it came out, the documentary-style horror movie terrified some audiences who weren’t so sure it was fiction. Here’s a look at its special alchemy and legacy.
item.dc:creator: Jake Kring-Schreifels

item.title: What America Gets Wrong About Tracy Flick
item.description: In “Election,” she’s preyed upon by a teacher and almost cheated out of her rightful victory. But somehow she’s the villain.
item.dc:creator: A.O. Scott

item.title: ‘The Nightingale’ Review: A Song of Violence and Vengeance
item.description: Jennifer Kent follows “The Babadook” with a harrowing, politically charged tale of sexual and racial brutality in 19th-century Tasmania.
item.dc:creator: A.O. Scott
item.media:description: Aisling Franciosi as an Irish convict seeking revenge in “The Nightingale.”

item.title: ‘Once Upon a Time … in Hollywood’ Has a Wild Ending. Let’s Talk.
item.description: Quentin Tarantino’s new film doesn’t quite wrap up the way you might expect.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.category: Once Upon a Time in Hollywood (Movie)
item.media:description: Brad Pitt as the stuntman Cliff Booth with his dog, Brandy, in Quentin Tarantino’s “Once Upon a Time … in Hollywood.”

item.title: ‘Luce’ Review: A Star Student Tests His Teacher’s Limits
item.description: To say that this feature unfolds like a play is both accurate and undersells just how gorgeously it has been rendered for the screen.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg
item.media:description: From left, Octavia Spencer, Kelvin Harrison Jr. and Naomi Watts in “Luce.”

item.title: ‘The Irishman’ Trailer: De Niro, Pacino and Scorsese at Work
item.description: It’s the first time the three have been on the same movie. This drama, from Netflix, involves the disappearance of the union leader Jimmy Hoffa.
item.dc:creator: Bruce Fretts

item.title: Have You Seen ‘Once Upon a Time … in Hollywood’? Here’s What to Read
item.description: Five books about or inspired by Charles Manson give insight into one of the 20th century’s most notorious crime sprees.
item.dc:creator: Concepción de León
item.category: The Family: The Story of Charles Manson's Dune Buggy Attack Battalion (Book)
Manson: The Life and Times of Charles Manson (Book)
Chaos: Charles Manson, the C.I.A. and the Secret History of the Sixties (Book)

item.title: ‘The Operative’ Review: High on Espionage, Low on Surprise
item.description: A bit of suspense and a good Diane Kruger performance notwithstanding, this thriller doesn’t have much new to offer.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg
item.media:description: Diane Kruger in “The Operative.”

item.title: 5 Film Series to Catch in N.Y.C. This Weekend
item.description: Our guide to film series and special screenings.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg
item.media:description: A scene from Michelangelo Antonioni’s “Zabriskie Point,” which will screen on Saturday and Sunday as part of Film at Lincoln Center’s Another Country: Outsider Visions of America.

item.title: ‘Hobbs & Shaw’ Review: Rock-em-Sock-em Bromance
item.description: This “Fast & Furious” spinoff featuring Dwayne Johnson and Jason Statham veers awfully close to rom-com territory.
item.dc:creator: Wesley Morris
item.media:description: Dwayne Johnson, left, and Jason Statham as teamed-up rivals — or are they?

item.title: ‘La Flor’ Review: Four Women in Search of a Movie
item.description: Mariano Llinás’s 13-hour cinematic puzzle is a labor of love and obsession.
item.dc:creator: A.O. Scott
item.media:description: From left, Santiago Gobernori, Laura Paredes and Elisa Carricajo in “La Flor.”

item.title: ‘The Son’ Review: She’s Having a Baby (Without You)
item.description: Where “Rosemary’s Baby” preyed on a mother’s loss of agency over her child, this Argentine thriller toys with a father’s utter superfluousness.
item.dc:creator: Scott Tobias
item.media:description: Joaquín Furriel in the Argentine film “The Son,” directed by Sebastián Schindel.

item.title: ‘Tel Aviv on Fire’ Review: Mideast Conflict as Soap Opera and Farce
item.description: Sameh Zoabi’s new film is less incendiary, and quite a bit funnier, than its title might suggest.
item.dc:creator: A.O. Scott
item.media:description: Kais Nashif as Salam, a Palestinian man who works for the show within the show in “Tel Aviv on Fire.”

item.title: One Night. One Chance. One Liza (With a ‘Z’).
item.description: Bob Fosse’s 1972 film of Liza Minnelli at the Lyceum Theater remains a spellbinding document of the art of performance.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas
item.category: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: NBC/NBCU Photo Bank via Getty Images
item.media:description: “I Gotcha”: Ms. Minnelli lights up the stage in Halston (he designed all of her clothes for the show) in “Liza With a ‘Z.’”

item.title: ‘Piranhas’ Review: Junior Mafia
item.description: It’s tough turf in the towns around Naples, Italy, and one teen aspires to take them over and become a crime kingpin in this drama.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny
item.media:description: Luca Nacarlo, left, and Francesco Di Napoli in “Piranhas.”

item.title: ‘Ladyworld’ Review: Fresh Talents Prove Themselves in a Twist on ‘Lord of the Flies’
item.description: Teenage girls, trapped and left to fend for themselves, establish a small, precarious society in Amanda Kramer’s film.
item.dc:creator: Teo Bugbee
item.media:description: Kramer uses tableaus to convey the group’s shifting dynamics.

item.title: ‘Them That Follow’ Review: Hiss of Death
item.description: A snake-handling Pentecostal pastor’s daughter faces a familiar romantic predicament in this dreary Appalachian tragedy.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis
item.media:description: Alice Englert in “Them That Follow.”

item.title: ‘A Score to Settle’ Review: Vengeance Is Fine
item.description: As a dying mobster of dubious mental clarity, Nicolas Cage could not be more perfect for Shawn Ku’s loopy revenge thriller.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis
item.media:description: Nicolas Cage has, and stars in, “A Score to Settle.”

item.title: ‘Jay Myself’ Review: A Photographer Parts With His SoHo Paradise
item.description: This documentary about Jay Maisel shows how a six-story building became his nest and a space for his hoardings.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny
item.media:description: The artist Jay Maisel, in his palace of curiosities, in “Jay Myself.”

item.title: ‘The Lighthouse’ Trailer: Robert Pattinson and Willem Dafoe Get Spooky
item.description: The 19th-century tale comes from the director Robert Eggers, who was responsible for “The Witch.”
item.dc:creator: Bruce Fretts

item.title: Martin Scorsese’s ‘The Irishman’ Will Open the New York Film Festival
item.description: The director’s big-budget Netflix film stars Robert De Niro, Al Pacino and Joe Pesci in a crime drama that features “de-aging” special effects.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy
item.media:description: Joe Pesci and Robert De Niro in “The Irishman.”

item.title: Korngold’s Rarely Heard Opera Hints at His Future in Hollywood
item.description: Bard SummerScape is offering the belated American premiere of “Das Wunder der Heliane” as part of a deep dive into Erich Wolfgang Korngold’s work.
item.dc:creator: Seth Colter Walls
item.media:description: Erich Wolfgang Korngold’s “Das Wunder der Heliane” is having its American premiere, nearly 100 years after it was written, at the Bard SummerScape festival.

item.title: ‘Once Upon a Time … in Hollywood’ Is a Box-Office Hit for Tarantino
item.description: Leonardo DiCaprio and Brad Pitt helped the director score one of the biggest opening weekends of his career.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Cohn
item.category: Once Upon a Time in Hollywood (Movie)
item.media:description: Brad Pitt, left, and Leonardo DiCaprio in “Once Upon a Time … in Hollywood.” The film opened to about $40.4 million in domestic ticket sales.

item.title: Before Making Features, These Filmmakers Cut Their Movies Down to Size
item.description: The feature version of the Oscar-winning short “Skin” is not simply an expansion, but, in the director’s view, its opposite.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg
item.media:description: Jamie Bell in “Skin,” directed by Guy Nattiv.

item.title: Denise Richards, the Un-Housewife
item.description: The actress has brought a refreshing and occasionally disarming dose of reality to “The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills.”
item.dc:creator: Ilana Kaplan
item.category: The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills (TV Program)
item.media:description: Denise Richards joined the cast of “The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills” this season, bringing to the show a casual attitude and frank discussions about sex and love.

item.title: Sharon Tate and ‘Once Upon a Time … in Hollywood’: What Actually Happened?
item.description: The up-and-coming actress, who was murdered at age 26 by Manson family members, was in “Valley of the Dolls” and “The Wrecking Crew.”
item.dc:creator: Nancy Coleman
item.category: Once Upon a Time in Hollywood (Movie)
item.media:description: The actress Sharon Tate on the set of “The Wrecking Crew.” Her role in the movie made its way into Quentin Tarantino’s “Once Upon a Time … in Hollywood.”

item.title: Solace and Salvation in the Marvel Universe, at 12 Cents a Comic Book
item.description: How Jack Kirby, Steve Ditko and Stan Lee shaped one boy’s life at a time when his family was in deep distress.
item.dc:creator: Dana Jennings

item.title: Angela Bassett Proves Who’s Queen in ‘Otherhood’
item.description: She talks about her new Netflix movie — and the recent travails of her co-star, Felicity Huffman.
item.dc:creator: Kathryn Shattuck
item.media:credit: Rozette Rago for The New York Times
item.media:description: When Angela Bassett read the script for “Otherhood,” she said, “I just thought it was hysterical — I was falling over.”

item.title: How Thor Transforms in ‘Avengers: Endgame’
item.description: Ahead of the film’s digital release, the directors Anthony and Joe Russo discuss a scene with Chris Hemsworth as a lackadaisical, beer-guzzling Thor.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: ‘Avengers: Endgame’ | Anatomy of a Scene
item.description: Anthony and Joe Russo narrate a sequence from their film featuring Chris Hemsworth.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: Review: ‘Moulin Rouge! The Musical’ Offers a Party, and a Playlist, for the Ages
item.description: Forbidden pleasures abound in this spectacular musical, starring a dazzling Karen Olivo as a doomed Parisian chanteuse.
item.dc:creator: Ben Brantley
item.media:description: Aaron Tveit as Christian and Karen Olivo as Satine in “Moulin Rouge! The Musical” at the Al Hirschfeld Theater.

item.title: ‘Boi’ Review: Being Driven to Distraction
item.description: A would-be novelist roams Barcelona as a chauffeur who is the captive of his own overactive imagination in this film by Jorge M. Fontana.
item.dc:creator: Helen T. Verongos
item.media:description: Miranda Gas and Bernat Quintana in the Spanish-language film “Boi,” from Jorge M. Fontana.
